alrighty, make it happen :)'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2018-03-19 17:32:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

(6 comments)'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2018-03-19 17:41:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

(5 comments)

Fixes in followup: https://review.openstack.org/554305'}, {'account_id': 17190, 'date': '2018-03-19 19:12:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

> (5 comments)
 > 
 > Fixes in followup: https://review.openstack.org/554305

Thanks Eric. Will look at the follow up.'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-04-06 12:58:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 17190, 'date': '2018-04-06 16:24:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

> (1 comment)

good point matt. I think it makes sense to placement everytime something change. 

How about a scenario where the flavor was updated with a new trait and now the instance is being rebuild.

Is the above supported? Is it considered a resize? in the above scenario, you would rebuild the image on the same node without considering the tratis.'}, {'account_id': 17190, 'date': '2018-04-06 16:38:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

> > (1 comment)
 > 
 > good point matt. I think it makes sense to placement everytime
 > something change.
 > 
 > How about a scenario where the flavor was updated with a new trait
 > and now the instance is being rebuild.
 > 
 > Is the above supported? Is it considered a resize? in the above
 > scenario, you would rebuild the image on the same node without
 > considering the tratis.

got clarification on IRC. for a resize we always use the original flavor, even if the flavor is updated after launch of instance. A copy of the flavor is persisted in the request spec.'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-04-06 18:10:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

> got clarification on IRC. for a resize we always use the original flavor, even if the flavor is updated after launch of instance. A copy of the flavor is persisted in the request spec.

A resize is moving to a new host with a new flavor but with the same image.

A rebuild is staying on the same host, with optionally a new image, but the flavor stays the same.'}]

commit_message:
Support traits in Glance

This blueprint proposes to extend the granular scheduling of compute
instances to be based on traits expressed in glance image metadata in
addition to the traits expressed by the flavor

Blueprint: glance-image-traits

Change-Id: I2ecd89d64cdc175c93d173cda9b3f1080cf47ff9

commit_message:
Fix stretch queens repo

This patch fixes the URLs for the stretch-queens Debian repo.
First, it uses the now standardized scheme for the backport
URL: http://<debian-release>-<openstack-release>.debian.net/debian,
maintained by the Debian OpenStack team.

Then it uses $::lsbdistcodename everywhere, to be able to work
with all Debian releases.

Finally, this patch fixes unit tests to work with stretch and queens
as default.

Change-Id: I96af5021c51d6db9946197f8bc187a386ae04f25
Co-Authored-By: Alex Schultz <aschultz@redhat.com>

subject: Fix check for api_versions ctx at required_services
messages: [{'account_id': 9545, 'date': '2018-04-06 11:10:36.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 9545, 'date': '2018-04-06 11:11:29.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 9545, 'date': '2018-04-06 16:36:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Workflow+1 Code-Review+2'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-04-06 11:10:36.000000000', 'message': 'Fix check for api_versions ctx at required_services validator

``required_services`` validator should not check services which are
configured via ``api_versions@openstack`` context since the proper validation
is done at the context itself.
The inner check for ``api_versions@openstack`` in ``required_services``
checked only ``api_versions@openstack``, but ``api_versions`` string is also
valid name for the context (if there is no other ``api_versions`` contexts

The inner check for ``api_versions@openstack`` in ``required_services``

commit_message:
Fix check for api_versions ctx at required_services

``required_services`` validator should not check services which are
configured via ``api_versions@openstack`` context since the proper validation
is done at the context itself.
The inner check for ``api_versions@openstack`` in ``required_services``
checked only ``api_versions@openstack``, but ``api_versions`` string is also
valid name for the context (if there is no other ``api_versions`` contexts
for other platforms, but the case of name conflict is covered by another
check).

Also, this patch moves several imports inside validators to reduce cost
of discovering plugins.

Change-Id: I70af451d33ad8f11ab1ee0df0e18a93d045cf195

commit_message:
Fix incompatible requirement in lower-constraints

Fix lower-constraints don't match the lower bounds
in the requirements file(s). It causes fail in
requirements-check.

REF:
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2018-April/129056.html

Change-Id: Ib71b09be0de1bd52d64eebed913ac1ee14f2d154

SUSE is behaving better and can now be tested in periodics safely,
as they should gate under the 3h mark.

commit_message:
Make two workflows from 'validations' produce output

Now two 'list' workflows don't return the result. This commit adds
"output" section to both of them.

Change-Id: Ide857991b570593a6e6b93097171edadf51e4fcd
Close-bug: #1761504
Related-bug: #1759417

commit_message:
Do not generate the html ARA report any more

With [1] we no longer need to generate the html report,
so in this patch we change the log collection process
in order to use the new mechanism.

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2018-March/128902.html

Change-Id: I6d7a9af234b7a8a6e83f9a730ffe1c4fd698786a
(cherry picked from commit e7b21c813ca9c53b02f4629c669b041c77b87c3e)

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-04-04 16:09:39.000000000', 'message': 'Include database in the default event dispatchers

since ceilometer still uses mongodb in newton for events, lets set that

commit_message:
Include database in the default event dispatchers

since ceilometer still uses mongodb in newton for events, lets set that
by default.

Closes-bug: #1761317

Change-Id: I6a4c4032040858d4c79ae128e8b083656c62fc8c

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-04-03 05:29:14.000000000', 'message': 'Formalise saving of /etc/resolv.conf

systemd-resolved has a new behaviour in bionic, in that if there is no
/etc/resolv.conf file when it installs, it assumes it is a fresh
system and makes /etc/resolf.conf a symlink into its compatability
files.

dib ends up saving & restoring whatever /etc/resolv.conf we have after
the inital chroot creation, which may not be what we want -- in the
above case it restores the system-resolved symlink.  For
openstack-infra, we use unbound and want simply "127.0.0.1" in a
/etc/resolv.conf file [1].

Formalise the ability to save specific contents into the final image.
Rename the file to save to DIB_ORIG to namespace it for dib.  Add
documentation, and a note in the code that it's an external interface.

[1] Note that systemd-resolved will obey /etc/resolv.conf as you would
expect, if file exists.

Change-Id: Ie0e97d8072e2b21a54b053fa6fb07b62960c686d

Change-Id: Ie0e97d8072e2b21a54b053fa6fb07b62960c686d

/etc/resolv.conf file when it installs, it assumes it is a fresh
system and makes /etc/resolf.conf a symlink into its compatability

dib ends up saving & restoring whatever /etc/resolv.conf we have after

commit_message:
Formalise saving of /etc/resolv.conf

systemd-resolved has a new behaviour in bionic, in that if there is no
/etc/resolv.conf file when it installs, it assumes it is a fresh
system and makes /etc/resolf.conf a symlink into its compatability
files.

dib ends up saving & restoring whatever /etc/resolv.conf we have after
the inital chroot creation, which may not be what we want -- in the
above case it restores the system-resolved symlink.  For
openstack-infra, we use unbound and want simply "127.0.0.1" in a
/etc/resolv.conf file [1].

Formalise the ability to save specific contents into the final image.
Add documentation, and a note in the code that it's an external
interface.

I would have preferred to namespace the .ORIG file with DIB_ or
similar, but this unofficial interface has already escaped into the
wild.  Leave it as is for simplicity.

[1] Note that systemd-resolved will obey /etc/resolv.conf as you would
expect, if file exists.

Change-Id: Ie0e97d8072e2b21a54b053fa6fb07b62960c686d

commit_message:
ironic-conductor: configure ipxe_timeout to 60

... to have parity with instack-undercloud, we will set:
ironic::drivers::pxe::ipxe_timeout: 60

Note: this is done via a new parameter, IronicIPXETimeout that can be
overriden by the user.

Change-Id: I9c558340517fc6590123e20b12ce75a40a6084dd

- To be aligned with how undercloud was configured, let's change some
defaults in Mistral Engine:

mistral::engine::evaluation_interval: 120
mistral::engine::older_than: 2880

- 2 new parameters are provided:

    MistralEvaluationInterval is a new parameter that allow to configure
    how often will the Mistral Executions be evaluated.
    For example for value 120 the interval will be 2 hours (every 2 hours).

    MistralFinishedExecutionDuration is a new parameter that allow to configure
    how Mistral will evaluate from which time remove executions in minutes.
    For example when set to 60, remove all executions that finished a 60 minutes
    ago or more.
    Note that only final state execution will remove (SUCCESS/ERROR).

Change-Id: Ia2c3e41a77aa44edacf4d03a6da829fbf33410b9
"}]
commit_message:
mistral: align parameters with undercloud

- To be aligned with how undercloud was configured, let's change some
defaults in Mistral Engine:

mistral::engine::evaluation_interval: 120
mistral::engine::older_than: 2880

- 2 new parameters are provided:

    MistralEvaluationInterval is a new parameter that allow to configure
    how often will the Mistral Executions be evaluated.
    For example for value 120 the interval will be 2 hours (every 2 hours).

    MistralFinishedExecutionDuration is a new parameter that allow to configure
    how Mistral will evaluate from which time remove executions in minutes.
    For example when set to 60, remove all executions that finished a 60 minutes
    ago or more.
    Note that only final state execution will remove (SUCCESS/ERROR).

Change-Id: Ia2c3e41a77aa44edacf4d03a6da829fbf33410b9

With the intention of improving the debugging

commit_message:
Log ansible and ansible-playbook command.

With the intention of improving the debugging
process, it has been added a log to display the
full ansible/ansible-playbook command run in the
tripleo.ansible/tripleo.ansible-playbook actions.

Change-Id: I26301b0bf9fe8b4a988575656fcd32bfaca1b3b1

(1 comment)

You need "new" added to the path. 

But now I wound, jose has taken another approach there, by reusing overcloud-upgrade playbook for undercloud-upgrade[1]

Now yours is clearer but have a lot of code duplication.  So maybe we should refactor the overcloud-upgrade-new/legacy to a role that is just called tripleo-upgrade in extra that make the glue and remove all duplication.

We would then use it in a playbook like yours for every stuff we need in the upgrade:

 - multinode-overcloud-upgrade
 - multinode-overcloud-update
 - multinode-undercloud-upgrade

WDYT ?

commit_message:
Overcloud update CI with tripleo-upgrade role

This adds update sub-playbook to the multinode playbook, it only gets
executed if overcloud-update tag is set.

Co-Authored-By: Jose Luis Franco <jfrancoa@redhat.com>
Related-Bug: #1749740
Change-Id: I75a358dea33c8befef37aceddeb02e30599d3f7a

commit_message:
Drop ubuntu 14.04 from spec tests

It is breaking the build on unit-4.8-centos-7 jobs with:

  pacemaker::new::service on ubuntu-14.04-x86_64 with default parameters should compile into a catalogue without dependency cycles
  Failure/Error: it { is_expected.to compile.with_all_deps }
  RuntimeError:
    Could not find the daemon directory (tested [/etc/sv,/var/lib/service])

Not sure it is worth investigating much more here, hence the dropping of
this older release.

Tested this in CI via "Iaadeaabcdb1598dce6ac17ba09672249c8cb631b"

Change-Id: Icc11d62df60871f0b77212ed1b814aa9623bf8fb

commit_message:
Fix incompatible requirement in lower-constraints

Fix lower-constraints don't match the lower bounds
in the requirements file(s). It causes fail in
requirements-check.

REF:
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2018-April/129056.html

commit_message:
[ci] Launch magnum job only for mangum changes

rally-task-magnum job takes too much time. It is a bit redundant to run
it on every rally-openstack change, so let's define files on which this
job should be triggered.

Change-Id: I05380018d9e2421329fd83677ace3ac03746abaf

subject: Closes-Bug: 1761604
messages:
[{'account_id': 20889, 'date': '2018-04-05 23:48:32.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 10068, 'date': '2018-04-05 23:48:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

    Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
    and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
    developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

    People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
    concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
    and resubmit a new change-set.

    Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
    available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
    takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
    reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
    rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
    people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
    eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
    reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

    Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

    IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC
    Workflow: http://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/developers.html
    Commit Messages: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GitCommitMessages"}, {'account_id': 20889, 'date': '2018-04-05 23:51:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow-1 Code-Review-1'}, {'account_id': 20889, 'date': '2018-04-05 23:52:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

commit_message:
bagpipe-bgp: make it optional to provide an IP for a port

Make it optional to provide an IP for a port, because in the
E-VPN case, it is not required.

This change also improves IP address validation, and validates
add MAC address validation.

(It also cleans up the exception a bit.)

Change-Id: I68365c3db33f0036f3a3c20e78bf5e210ce2f6a1

commit_message:
Fix xstatic copying

dest needs to be a directory, use ansible_user_dir since that's the
directory the file is executed from.

Change-Id: Icf109d41eb51e22ed0078e09c580a840d8d41950

Install heat-dashboard in rpm based distros

The heat-dashboard was recently packaged in RDO [1], let's add it to
the rpm based distros.

 [1] https://github.com/rdo-packages/heat-dashboard-distgit

Change-Id: I0652e172f3651b427805aa3673527677bd3429d8
Related-Bug: #1752132
(cherry picked from commit b3390c97f2b7b48048a02e84d54ac4503e765ed1)

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

    Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
    and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
    developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

    People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
    concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
    and resubmit a new change-set.

    Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
    available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
    takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
    reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
    rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
    people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
    eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
    reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

    Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

commit_message:
Do not use async parameter

We have method passthru that is accepting parameter async,
but since python 3.7 use async as reserved word,
the async parameter is deprecated,
async_call should be used instead.
async parameter will be removed in the next cycle.

Change-Id: I6299aafd30faae9a93df2cb901c1505df47e6b45
Task: 9289
Story: 1751306

commit_message:
Removal of deprecated direct driver loading

The direct loading of drivers was deprecated in Liberty and noted
to be removed in Newton. This patch cleans up the deprecation and
fixes the unit tests. Some of the example request/response json
message bodies of the domain config API were also updated to the
correct way of loading a driver now.

bp removed-as-of-rocky

Change-Id: If3f4c2303da6e264e5e0d73280cc21fa01a3cfd4

can't find an image property. The following error is

Change-Id: I399c647fbf67236bdfa2a7a09ef63cd0c5df8b26

commit_message:
Update image in magnum jobs

In current magnum job failures, magnum is trying
to use an image that doesn't exist and therefore it
can't find an image property. The following error is
the result: BadRequest: Cluster type (vm, Unset, swarm)
not supported (HTTP 400).

Change-Id: I399c647fbf67236bdfa2a7a09ef63cd0c5df8b26

commit_message:
add lower-constraints job

Create a tox environment for running the unit tests against the lower
bounds of the dependencies.

Create a lower-constraints.txt to be used to enforce the lower bounds
in those tests.

Add openstack-tox-lower-constraints job to the zuul configuration.

See http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2018-March/128352.html
for more details.

Change-Id: Ia0df9d71a43832405bb408967349ad84a6f73d5c
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/555034
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-04-04 20:20:03.000000000', 'message': "[placement] Fix incorrect exception import

In change I2b94945a0963d6a61af931505b69afe2d4733759 the exceptions that
placement uses were moved into the placement hierarchy and most of the
code that uses those exceptions was updated to reflect the change.

I86416e35da1798cdf039b42c9ed7629f0f9c75fc merged slightly before,
and had not made the change to the new style.

As the old aggregate handler had no exceptions imported, there was no
merge conflict when the exceptions change merged. At the same time
the exception in question is not covered by tests, because it only
happens if there is a concurrent update, which we don't cover in the
gabbi tests. We do cover a generation conflict on a supplied
generation, but that's not the same thing.

So basically this went by without us noticing and I happened to notice
while doing something else, so here's a fix for it.

Change-Id: I4b7b29270b2d9900b59c7dd74082688164430252
Closes-Bug: #1761295
"}, {'created': '2018-04-04 21:34:33.000000000', 'message': "[placement] Fix incorrect exception import

In change I2b94945a0963d6a61af931505b69afe2d4733759 the exceptions that
placement uses were moved into the placement hierarchy and most of the
code that uses those exceptions was updated to reflect the change.

I86416e35da1798cdf039b42c9ed7629f0f9c75fc merged slightly before,
and had not made the change to the new style.

As the old aggregate handler had no exceptions imported, there was no
merge conflict when the exceptions change merged. At the same time
the exception in question is not covered by tests, because it only
happens if there is a concurrent update, which we don't cover in the
gabbi tests. We do cover a generation conflict on a supplied
generation, but that's not the same thing.

So basically this went by without us noticing and I happened to notice
while doing something else, so here's a fix for it.

To test it, a new directory for unit tests for handlers is added and
a new file, test_aggregate. Following the guidelines in
https://docs.openstack.org/nova/latest/contributor/placement.html#testing
the problematic code has been extracted to its own private method so that
it can be tested as a unit with limited mocking. The overarching flow
of setting aggregates continues to be tested by the gabbi functional
tests.

Note the added NOTE in the new _set_aggregates method: It appears that
the DBDuplicateEntry exception maybe doesn't need to be there.

Change-Id: I4b7b29270b2d9900b59c7dd74082688164430252
Closes-Bug: #1761295
"}, {'created': '2018-04-05 17:46:42.000000000', 'message': "[placement] Fix incorrect exception import

commit_message:
[placement] Fix incorrect exception import

In change I2b94945a0963d6a61af931505b69afe2d4733759 the exceptions that
placement uses were moved into the placement hierarchy and most of the
code that uses those exceptions was updated to reflect the change.

I86416e35da1798cdf039b42c9ed7629f0f9c75fc merged slightly before,
and had not made the change to the new style.

As the old aggregate handler had no exceptions imported, there was no
merge conflict when the exceptions change merged. At the same time
the exception in question is not covered by tests, because it only
happens if there is a concurrent update, which we don't cover in the
gabbi tests. We do cover a generation conflict on a supplied
generation, but that's not the same thing.

So basically this went by without us noticing and I happened to notice
while doing something else, so here's a fix for it.

To test it, a new directory for unit tests for handlers is added and
a new file, test_aggregate. Following the guidelines in
https://docs.openstack.org/nova/latest/contributor/placement.html#testing
the problematic code has been extracted to its own private method so that
it can be tested as a unit with limited mocking. The overarching flow
of setting aggregates continues to be tested by the gabbi functional
tests.

Note the added NOTE in the new _set_aggregates method: It appears that
the DBDuplicateEntry exception maybe doesn't need to be there.

Change-Id: I4b7b29270b2d9900b59c7dd74082688164430252
Closes-Bug: #1761295

commit_message:
Added monitoring tag to monitoring user creation task.

Without that tag, the monitoring user doesn't have the proper privileges
to access the management API to collect metrics. Check the Permission
section in RabbitMQ documentation at https://www.rabbitmq.com/management.html
for futher precision regarding the permission model.

Closes-Bug: 1750582
Change-Id: Iebf279ca591e646656f8411934fd58dc43d5f002

OVH nodepool nodes have an issue which causes nested virt
instances to crash with a hardware error, then a dump.
We therefore detect whether we're running on OVH and
force it to use qemu instead.

Change-Id: I54681092adf9c0647bf65583176ddc21c99494f3
(cherry picked from commit cc98ed84f166cc7dd09ff0157764b3f4d06391b6)
"}]
commit_message:
Work around nested virt issues on OVH test nodes

OVH nodepool nodes have an issue which causes nested virt
instances to crash with a hardware error, then a dump.
We therefore detect whether we're running on OVH and
force it to use qemu instead.

Change-Id: I54681092adf9c0647bf65583176ddc21c99494f3
(cherry picked from commit cc98ed84f166cc7dd09ff0157764b3f4d06391b6)

commit_message:
add lower-constraints job

Create a tox environment for running the unit tests against the lower
bounds of the dependencies.

Create a lower-constraints.txt to be used to enforce the lower bounds
in those tests.

Add openstack-tox-lower-constraints job to the zuul configuration.

See http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2018-March/128352.html
for more details.

Change-Id: I911c66b2e9971a3e134c482a4b4ffa529d358a76
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/555034
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

LiquidioCompute nodes use OS::TripleO::Services::LiquidioCompute
to apply necessary configuration. This service declaration is
currently missing in overcloud puppet service registry file.
Without this declaration, respective role can not be used.

Change-Id: I17af0945feb5be2450dbcd4f29f861d57d2db205
Closes-Bug: 1760544
(cherry picked from commit 8f24db876c9a5472d99f32d252a349e8ee8b9d2b)

commit_message:
Added Liquidio service definition in overcloud puppet registry

LiquidioCompute nodes use OS::TripleO::Services::LiquidioCompute
to apply necessary configuration. This service declaration is
currently missing in overcloud puppet service registry file.
Without this declaration, respective role can not be used.

Change-Id: I17af0945feb5be2450dbcd4f29f861d57d2db205
Closes-Bug: 1760544
(cherry picked from commit 8f24db876c9a5472d99f32d252a349e8ee8b9d2b)

commit_message:
Change container registry file to the default paremters

As stated in https://review.openstack.org/#/c/535859/19 the file has changed and now,
the docker images are expressed as default_parameters.

It fix problems like this:

:8787/tripleomaster/centos-binary-rabbitmq:ad1779c561edabdd6446c5fa39f05e121a327d7f_710b9460'}, {u'imagename': u'192.168.24.1:8787/tripleomaster/centos-binary-rsyslog-base:ad1779c561edabdd6446c5fa39f05e121a327d7f_710b9460'}]}}']
'parameter_defaults': KeyError: 'parameter_defaults'
mistral.executors.default_executor Traceback (most recent call last):
mistral.executors.default_executor File "/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/mistral/executors/default_executor.py", line 114, in run_action
mistral.executors.default_executor result = action.run(action_ctx)
mistral.executors.default_executor File "/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/tripleo_common/actions/package_update.py", line 82, in run
mistral.executors.default_executor parameters.update(self.container_registry['parameter_defaults'])
mistral.executors.default_executor KeyError: 'parameter_defaults'

Change-Id: I8030db471260151df2059085eac496d6538f4882

commit_message:
Add heat dashboard for deb/ubuntu binary

The python-heat-dashboard was missing from Debian/Ubuntu binary horizon
images. This commit adds it since the deb package is now available in
the repositories.

Change-Id: Id0462419b97b8f1027a3ed9190b3ef57af8a7e3d

commit_message:
Add tripleo-ui docker service to undercloud config

This change teaches the new containerized undercloud deploy command to
understand the `enable_ui` configuration option, and to correctly add the
`tripleo-ui.yaml` environment file to the list of deployment arguments.

Depends-On: I279faf3f5ec42b25cc2d374ccd9108366b7a2733
Depends-On: Ibc739ed87093000b4b0f6d318b1a9499037377bd
Partially-Implements: bp tripleo-ui-undercloud-container

commit_message:
Handle lack of certificate in DevStack

This commit fixes issue with creation of Kuryr Secret with CA
certificate when certificate doesn't exist. Basically it makes sure that
in that case the CA cert file will be empty.

Closes-Bug: 1760825

Change-Id: I519ef424e00584ea471d6707d916cd30b94b06bf

commit_message:
Support --ssh-user argument to upgrade/update run command

To allow upgrading both Nova based and Deployed Server based
environments, we introduced --ssh-user argument (until all envs have
tripleo-admin user).

Note: CLI for FFWD upgrade is being implemented, so a --ssh-user patch
to tripleo-upgrade FFWD will have to follow later.

Related-Bug: #1759845
Depends-On: I0df57002b2305c1e2504c9f7a7d0c326d8ffcaf7
Change-Id: Ib486a812aa9fd96bc753eda122cd05682d97b209

commit_message:
Generate inventory with tripleo-admin user

This is already the default when we generate the inventory via Mistral
workflow [1]. By using heat-admin we cannot connect to Deployed Server
environments, which e.g. affects CI, so we should use the same default
that the Mistral workflow uses nowadays.

[1] https://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/tripleo-common/tree/tripleo_common/actions/ansible.py#n526

Partial-Bug: #1757090
Change-Id: Idc0dba7a119efedae7f762d3a351419c22584b61

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-04-06 09:25:02.000000000', 'message': "DHCP agent: take hostname from Neutron 'host' config

If a deployer wants to use a hostname for Felix other than the natural
hostname, this allows them to set that same hostname for the DHCP agent
to pick up, so that the DHCP agent will look for the correct endpoint
resources in etcd.

Change-Id: I3b144085a6e5505d2b1f2efe2341945175ded871
"}]
commit_message:
DHCP agent: take hostname from Neutron 'host' config

If a deployer wants to use a hostname for Felix other than the natural
hostname, this allows them to set that same hostname for the DHCP agent
to pick up, so that the DHCP agent will look for the correct endpoint
resources in etcd.

Change-Id: I3b144085a6e5505d2b1f2efe2341945175ded871

I think there is still a much cleaner solution. The problem stems from a full page refresh hitting the server side routing (provided by Django), which doesn't have ngdetails route because that's provided by the client. Can you not just add something like `url(r'^ngdetails/', AngularIndexView.as_view())` to openstack_dashboard/urls.py, and let the angular router parse the rest once it hits the index view?"}, {'account_id': 16352, 'date': '2017-08-10 06:56:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

The proposal that like you said had been already rejected by Akihiro. https://review.openstack.org/#/c/477447/7/horizon/site_urls.py@45
I wonder which is better the increasing URL registration (but seems secure(?), Akihiro's opinion) or one registration (maybe have better performance).
Anyway since panel and dashboard info for setting nav and breadcrumb are needed to load ngdetails even if using AngularIndexView, so the implementations to get thier info will be left. It is reason for that I make AngularDetailsView inheriting AngularIndexView. The difficulties to get panel and dashboard bother us."}, {'account_id': 16352, 'date': '2017-08-10 06:58:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

I'm already in vacation until Aug 21. So I'll restart this 22nd."}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2017-08-10 08:23:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

Although I commented in https://review.openstack.org/#/c/477447/, iti is not a good idea to catch all URLs starting with /ngdetails/, I think it is a balance.

If we register Django views it is better to register minimum URLs and let Django return 404.

In AngularJS case, we cannot let Django determine which resource is available, so catching all URLs with /ngdetails/ is acceptable I think. We have a merit that we don't need to have duplicated logic in Angular and Django sides.

Anyway, I would like to see appropriate 404 for non-existing detail pages (both for non-existing resource types and non-existing resources i.e. UUIDs)


I think Rob's idea is 
My comment"}, {'account_id': 25747, 'date': '2017-08-11 00:32:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 12826, 'date': '2017-08-14 07:54:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

+1 Akihiro. The problem here is not performance, but adding extra architecture that is mysterious to non-Horizon devs. People will forget to add this parameter and run into errors all the time. Adding the ngdetails/<resource> url is a much nicer situation.'}, {'account_id': 16352, 'date': '2017-08-22 09:32:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

@Rob, I had tried to implement at first like you said. But I met the misteries that need to set dash and panel for nav-bar and breadcrumb, so this patch updated like this. If you have better way to refresh ngdetails, could you clarify your strategy in https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/refresh-ngdetails'}, {'account_id': 16707, 'date': '2017-08-23 06:21:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 16352, 'date': '2017-08-23 06:39:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

`ngdetails` is global module and route for `ngdetails` registered globally at https://github.com/openstack/horizon/blob/master/openstack_dashboard/static/app/core/core.module.js#L66 . So to route to ngdetails, originally no needed to redirect to index view once. If redirect to index view once, index view needs to redirect again to ngdetails/[id]. It's not good to increase the number of HTTP request, I think. Also, to get panel from resource type, it needs panel instance and dashboard. These procedure is almost same as this patch. See alternative patchset: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/496511/"}, {'account_id': 16352, 'date': '2017-08-24 01:00:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

In any case, we can not set proper nav bar and breadcrumb without association between resource type and panel. Only if we can set the default dashboard and panel to it anytime, ignoring proper settings for sidebar and breadcrumb, we can remove the codes for association between resource type and panel.'}, {'account_id': 16352, 'date': '2017-09-01 08:38:35.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 16352, 'date': '2017-09-01 08:48:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

I changed this implementations according to third idea. I think the biggest concern for the previous patch was that the setting needs to be set for each resource. This is still needed with this patch but it's in a less distracted way. The additional code for the sidebar and breadcrumb in this patch was not needed in the previous patch, but I think it's reusable as in the patch based on this. Groups, keypairs, and flavors should have this change too. Also, when refreshing from a panel under admin dashboard, the panel to show should be the one under admin not project."}, {'account_id': 16352, 'date': '2017-10-19 05:17:21.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 13.'}, {'account_id': 16352, 'date': '2017-10-19 05:34:56.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 13:

@Ying, great thanks for your reviewing! Added this change for keypairs panel. Groups and flavors panel don't have details view yet. About groups panel, I'll add this change when add details view, if needed. Flavors panel doesn't seem to need details panel, since its information is not so much. The URL for ng-details view doesn't have information whether the details view referred from admin or project side. So we can't determine whether admin or project side we should dispatch when refreshing from browser."}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2017-10-19 09:48:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 13:

I think the ngdetail approach itself has a problem essentially from the point of view of that there is no way to determine a dashboard (admin/project/identity/...). It assumes a detail page is always called from some other page and it does not consider a case of reloading or specifying URL directly. IMHO ngdetail URLs should include a dashboard name, but it is beyond the scope of the patch I think.'}, {'account_id': 11885, 'date': '2017-10-23 02:49:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 13: Code-Review-1

If the page is always redirected to the project details panel, it won't work if the resource is not in the current project. I think we need to keep track of the page history so we know which dashboard this is from and be able to go back to the previous panel, which is needed for the patch depending on this."}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2017-10-23 07:24:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 13:

In my understanding, this patch tries to address two problems. The one is to allow to refresh ngdetail view. The other is to open ngdetail view directly by specifying an URL. Looking at the page history works for the first case (refresh), but it does not work for the second case.'}, {'account_id': 12826, 'date': '2017-10-24 10:39:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 13: Code-Review-1

I'm not really happy with this solution.

The problem arises because Django is unaware of the Angular router, so when you try to route directly to a URL that is angular-routed (either by a full page refresh, or a direct link) Django will attempt to resolve the URL and fail. This is a common problem across all SPA frameworks with client-side routing.

The standard solution is to either implement a fallback for all routes (i.e., routing all unknown routes to a base angular page, and have that serve the 404 itself) or, give nthat we really only have one failing route, manually add that route ("/ngdetails") to the base Django routing and serve the Angular index page; at this point, the Angular router should be able to intercept and correctly redirect.'}, {'account_id': 16352, 'date': '2017-10-26 10:02:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 13:

@Ying, I had also thought about seeking history when refreshing the details view. But considering direct link, I abandaned seeking it as this patch may be more bigger.
@Akihiro, thank you for your perfect understandings and replying instead of me!
@Rob, horizon/base.py and horizon/browser/views.py would enable what you said. But index views need to be set dashboard and panel object in the request object. If we simply append "/ngdetails" to urlpatterns and register index view for the URL, django cases 500 error when setting up side bar and breadcrumb. Most struggling point in this patch is to reproduce side bar and breadcrumb.'}, {'account_id': 16352, 'date': '2017-11-16 08:21:43.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 14.'}, {'account_id': 16352, 'date': '2017-11-16 08:24:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14:

For easier understanding, I divided this patch into the part for enabling reload and the other for reproducing navigations. Almost looks good.

I tested several scenarios. It worked well for most major scenarios.

- Reload project image detail -> Good
- Reload admin image detail -> Good
- Open project image detail directly from other panel -> Good (navigation menu was recovered correctly)
- Open admin image detail directly from other project -> Good (navigation menu was recovered correctly)
- Open admin image detail directly [1] (with 'demo' user, i.e., without admin role) -> The image detail is shown but no navigation menu is focused. I am not sure what is the expected behavior. My personal vote is to handle it as Not Found, but I have no strong opinion. At least no navigation menu is a bit confusing. This might be challenged as a separate bug.

[1] http://sheep6:8000/ngdetails/OS::Glance::Image/ce46ef50-850a-46ed-8707-bd5b21e4f9b7?nav=%2Fadmin%2Fimages%2F"}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2018-03-25 15:46:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 18:

revisions:
[{'created': '2017-08-07 05:48:40.000000000', 'message': "Enable to refresh ngdetails view

For now, refreshing ngdetails view by browser using F5 key or reload
button, it causes 404 error from django. To fix this issue, this patch
adds the url for '/ngdetails'.

Furthermore, to specify current navigation and to check access grants
to current panel, for navigation on left side and breadcrumbs, each
access to Horizon django framework needs its dashboard and panel
objects. It means that to show navigation and breadcrumbs properly in
refreshing ngdetails view, we need to specify dashboard and panel that
ngdetails view belongs to.

To specify the proper dashboard and panel that ngdetails view belongs to,
add resource_types attribute into Panel class.

Without resource_types attribute in Panel class, this attaches the
ngdetails view to default dashboard and panel.

Also, this patch adds the resource_types attribute existing Panels
that have Angularized details view.

Change-Id: I2edd44e55eb10114e5282cec1762e9635881f733
Closes-Bug: #1681627

"}, {'created': '2017-09-01 08:38:35.000000000', 'message': "Enable to refresh ngdetails view

For now, refreshing ngdetails view by browser using F5 key or reload
button, it causes 404 error from django. To fix this issue, this patch
adds the url for '/ngdetails'.

This patch makes django enable to route '/ngdetails' with navigation
(i.e. side bar and breadcrumb) specifying default dashboard and panel.

Also, to setup proper navigation to side bar and breadcrumb,
this patch adds new 'defaultIndexUrl' parameter and its getter/setter
into resource-type-service.

The 'defaultIndexUrl' parameter makes details view enable to set
navigations properly in Angular-side.

Each panel module should set URL for default index view using
'defaultIndexUrl' parameter. So, this patch adds the `defaultIndexUrl`
parameter into existing panel modules that have Angularized details view.

Change-Id: I2edd44e55eb10114e5282cec1762e9635881f733
Closes-Bug: #1681627

commit_message:
Reproduce navigations on refreshing ngdetails view

To setup proper navigation to side bar and breadcrumb,
this patch adds new 'defaultIndexUrl' parameter and
its getter/setter into resource-type-service.

The 'defaultIndexUrl' parameter makes details view
enable to set navigations properly in Angular-side.

Each panel module should set URL for default index view
using 'defaultIndexUrl' parameter. So, this patch adds
the `defaultIndexUrl` parameter into existing panel
modules that have Angularized details view.

Also, if query string has 'nav' parameter, the
navigation setting will be overwitten with it.
This URL overwriting may be used by panels that has
multiple index panels, like images panel.

Change-Id: I2edd44e55eb10114e5282cec1762e9635881f733
Closes-Bug: #1746706

commit_message:
bagpipe-bgp: make it optional to provide an IP for a port

Make it optional to provide an IP for a port, because in the
E-VPN case, it is not required.

Change-Id: Iaf7311d7ca5d4ac13d41861b2bc7e92bd764d83a

commit_message:
update_provider_tree devref and docstring updates

Design changes [1] from the Dublin PTG prompted some rewording of the
docstring for ComputeDriver.update_provider_tree.  And to avoid that
docstring becoming too enormous, relevant chunks of the spec [2] are
copied to a new devref document which is linked from that docstring.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/552122/
[2] http://specs.openstack.org/openstack/nova-specs/specs/rocky/approved/update-provider-tree.html

Change-Id: I06504aa2a3fe6d39ecc1e681de43be8fee9e06f6
blueprint: update-provider-tree

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-04-05 16:32:46.000000000', 'message': 'Containers without IPC mode always are restarted during deploy

With newer versions of Docker containers that run with default
IPC mode (set to "") always are restarted even if deployed
earlier. This is due to the difference how their IPC mode is
reported by the daemon. Usually if mode is set to "" a new
container is run with "shareable" mode, i.e. the mode
is taken from daemon defaults, see [1]. After that kolla_docker
module incorrectly compares the modes and restarts the container.

[1] https://docs.docker.com/engine/reference/run/#ipc-settings---ipc

Change-Id: I4497a4132f7810e96c540e0b4d6a37094a8a9204
Closes-Bug: #1761524
'}]
commit_message:
Containers without IPC mode always are restarted during deploy

With newer versions of Docker containers that run with default
IPC mode (set to "") always are restarted even if deployed
earlier. This is due to the difference how their IPC mode is
reported by the daemon. Usually if mode is set to "" a new
container is run with "shareable" mode, i.e. the mode
is taken from daemon defaults, see [1]. After that kolla_docker
module incorrectly compares the modes and restarts the container.

[1] https://docs.docker.com/engine/reference/run/#ipc-settings---ipc

Change-Id: I4497a4132f7810e96c540e0b4d6a37094a8a9204
Closes-Bug: #1761524

commit_message:
[Trivial]Add coverage for creating snapshot from non-blank volume

Now there is no coverage for creating snapshot from non-blank
volume in api tests, and because this is a basic function that
is often required by cloud users, this is to make a trivial fix
to cover it.

Change-Id: I0ce1b73ad54a4f4551478de82652d4b82444c312

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-04-05 01:09:43.000000000', 'message': 'Support unicode characters in tempauth user names.

Unicode characters in tempauth user names currently prevent these users
from authenticating. This manifests in two places:
1. the call to get_groups() fails to return a set that matches the user
   preventing authentication
2. a new token is generated every time for such users, as the check
   against existing memcache entries always fails to match

The patch fixes the existing behavior with respect to unicode users. As
part of it, the FakeMemcache class had to change to decode the strings
passed to it to mimic the actual memcache client behavior.

Darrell Bishop developed the patch and Timur Alperovich added the tests
for it.

Change-Id: I4ecfae2bca6ffa08ad15e584579ebce707f4628d

2. a new token is generated every time for such users, as the check

The patch fixes the existing behavior with respect to unicode users. As
part of it, the FakeMemcache class had to change to decode the strings
passed to it to mimic the actual memcache client behavior.

Darrell Bishop developed the patch and Timur Alperovich added the tests
for it.

Change-Id: I4ecfae2bca6ffa08ad15e584579ebce707f4628d
'}]
commit_message:
Support unicode characters in tempauth user names.

Unicode characters in tempauth user names currently prevent these users
from authenticating. This manifests in two places:
1. the call to get_groups() fails to return a set that matches the user
   preventing authentication
2. a new token is generated every time for such users, as the check
   against existing memcache entries always fails to match

The patch fixes the existing behavior with respect to unicode users. As
part of it, the FakeMemcache class had to change to decode the strings
passed to it to mimic the actual memcache client behavior.

Darrell Bishop developed the patch and Timur Alperovich added the tests
for it.

Change-Id: I4ecfae2bca6ffa08ad15e584579ebce707f4628d

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-04-05 16:18:06.000000000', 'message': 'Install neutron lbaasv2 extension for octavia

Octavia is installed w/o adding the lbaasv2 extension
to Neutron. That means that Heat does not recognize
OS::Neutron::LBaaS::* resources, so Heat templates that
could work with either Octavia or LBaasV2 can only work
with one or the other.

Note, there is no need to fully install neutron-lbaas
to have the lbaasv2 extension listed. The neutron-lbaas
package is installed in the neutron-server container,
so only adding the extension for octavia should work.
In the end, the calls to octavia would go via neutron-lbaas.

Change-Id: Idc45d8b30e25c4c0c66738ad9e1154a0ec4fceec
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobreli@redhat.com>
'}]
commit_message:
Install neutron lbaasv2 extension for octavia

Octavia is installed w/o adding the lbaasv2 extension
to Neutron. That means that Heat does not recognize
OS::Neutron::LBaaS::* resources, so Heat templates that
could work with either Octavia or LBaasV2 can only work
with one or the other.

Note, there is no need to fully install neutron-lbaas
to have the lbaasv2 extension listed. The neutron-lbaas
package is installed in the neutron-server container,
so only adding the extension for octavia should work.
In the end, the calls to octavia would go via neutron-lbaas.

Change-Id: Idc45d8b30e25c4c0c66738ad9e1154a0ec4fceec
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobreli@redhat.com>

subject: Reject metrics furure and past metrics
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 11809, 'name': 'Craig Bryant', 'email': 'craig.bryant@hpe.com', 'username': 'craig-bryant'}, {'_account_id': 15027, 'name': 'Michael Hoppal', 'email': 'michael.jam.hoppal@hpe.com', 'username': 'michael-hoppal'}, {'_account_id': 16222, 'name': 'witek', 'email': 'witold.bedyk@suse.com', 'username': 'witek'}, {'_account_id': 18179, 'name': 'Kaiyan Sheng', 'email': 'kaiyan.sheng@hpe.com', 'username': 'kaiyan-sheng'}, {'_account_id': 22157, 'name': 'Andrea Adams', 'email': 'aadams@hpe.com', 'username': 'andrea.adams'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 26639, 'name': 'Tobias Johansson', 'email': 'tjohansson@op5.com', 'username': 'tobiajo'}, {'_account_id': 26702, 'name': 'Nicolas Seyvet', 'email': 'nseyvet@op5.com', 'username': 'nseyvet'}, {'_account_id': 26733, 'name': 'Amir Mofakhar', 'email': 'amir@mofakhar.info', 'username': 'amofakhar'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 22157, 'date': '2018-02-10 00:07:49.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 22157, 'date': '2018-02-10 00:08:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow-1

Needs more testing'}, {'account_id': 26702, 'date': '2018-02-10 10:49:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

The monasca API needs to be able to ingest data in the past as well as in the future.  The most critical reason is to avoid data loss.  E.G. an old agent that comes back online needs to be able to send the data to the API. An external application wants to send data for threshold management, etc.  Moreover an external system (like a ML prediction) needs to be able to post metrics in the future.

All in all this feature if it gets implemented needs to be disabled by default and with both a higher and lower bound configurable.  It is unlikely that 2 minutes is a the ideal value and thus needs to be configurable.  Idem for two weeks in the past.

I am unsure DST would not affect the boundaries.  Basically during DST, 2 weeks is not equal to 2 x 14 x 24h, ie TWO_WEEKS = 2 * 7 * 24 * 60 * 60 * 1000 is false.'}, {'account_id': 11809, 'date': '2018-02-10 17:14:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

@nicolas Regarding the two weeks, a delta of two weeks is computed by the number of seconds between now (in seconds since the epoch) and the timestamp of the metric (also seconds since the epoch). DST has no effect on that delta just on the representation of the timestamps as a Date and Time.

As Andrea has stated, the Java implementation of the API (the original API for Monasca) always had this behavior. It was not added to the Python implementation of the API so many people don't know of the old behavior. Since this is effectively new behavior, I agree it should be configurable with the default being off. The default is off but the deltas need to be configurable as well.

Unfortunately, the most common reason for the timestamps being off is the source system is not configured with NTP. The Threshold Engine uses the timestamps of the metrics to determine  Alarm state and if the time gets off by just a couple of minutes it will end up dropping the metrics so time drift can be a big issue."}, {'account_id': 26702, 'date': '2018-02-11 17:06:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Other potential delays in timestamps are network issues, and split-brain for example.  A client may lose connection for many days.  Is there a requirement that every timestamp source must be synchronized to use Monasca?

Let's discuss the effects on the threshold engine in the IRC channel as  I do not understand the benefits of this change.

In addition to default off and configurable upper and lower bounds, this patch requires test cases."}, {'account_id': 16222, 'date': '2018-02-12 09:09:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

Andrea, could you please create a story describing the motivation and proposed configuration options?

I agree with Nicolas and Craig that the length of both intervals should be configurable. Also tests should be added.

Would you be available to discuss it in the team meeting on Wednesday? If so, please add it to the agenda [1].

[1] https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/monasca-team-meeting-agenda'}, {'account_id': 22157, 'date': '2018-02-12 20:21:51.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 22157, 'date': '2018-02-12 20:29:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Nicolas, Good idea to make both of the deltas configurable. That will let the user define a reasonable window for their own usecase.
Witold and Nicolas, I have added tests, let me know if you would like to see any other testing.
Witold, I have added a story. Hopefully this helps explain my motivation a little bit. I have also added this review to the meeting agenda, so that we can discuss any questions, comments or concerns there.'}, {'account_id': 22157, 'date': '2018-02-12 23:45:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 26702, 'date': '2018-02-13 08:48:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 16222, 'date': '2018-02-13 09:16:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 22157, 'date': '2018-02-13 20:43:44.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 22157, 'date': '2018-02-13 20:44:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

commit_message:
Reject metrics furure and past metrics

The Python Monasca API should reject metrics outside of some
reasonable time window. Wrong timestamps are probably
symptomatic of an NTP problem and should not make it to the
Threshold engine because that leads to inaccurate alarm and
notification evaluations.

Story: 2001535
Task: 6340

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/542945
Change-Id: I69c2bd547a5d2f63c62ffdc9b07df6be6e599c6c

commit_message:
DHCP agent: stop and restart after a number of cancelled watches

Each cancelled watch leaks a connection to the etcd server - see
https://github.com/dims/etcd3-gateway/issues/15 - so to work around that
we stop and restart after 20 cancelled watches.

Change-Id: Ie7f3a1ec447cd9efc320d98e0ff8959b39440748

subject: Respect X-Backend-Etag-Is-At headers from left of SLO
messages:
[{'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2018-03-27 00:00:00.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 4608, 'date': '2018-04-02 08:38:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

(4 comments)

Basically this looks fine to me but there is a point I'm still not sure so +1 for now until Tim answered to my question."}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2018-04-03 19:05:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2

I think this makes sense. SLO always replaces the response's ETag and Content-Length headers with its own, even if there'x an X-Backend-Etag-Is-At header set in the request. Presumably, the middleware responsible for setting X-Backend-Etag-Is-At will replace the responses' ETag with yet another value once control reaches that middleware."}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2018-04-03 20:42:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

(2 comments)

It's as Sam said -- the most sane way to do this that I could think of was to have SLO send its notion of Etag on, and let whoever set the X-Backend-Etag-Is-At header be in charge of replacing that with its own notion of Etag. This seems to match the example set by EC (and to a degree, encryption).

FWIW, as I was working on this I felt like we could probably find a way to get rid of the conditional_etag param to swob.Response entirely, and have the Response determine the appropriate value on its own. For now, though, I think I prefer the targeted fix first, and the more invasive refactoring later."}, {'account_id': 4608, 'date': '2018-04-06 06:25:57.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Workflow+1 Code-Review+2

(2 comments)

Make sense. I'm still thinking about how we can resolve the duplicate conditional check and the complexity of etag consistency but at least this patch works fine as a bug fix so it's fine to me to merge this as it is.

Thanks."}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-03-27 00:00:00.000000000', 'message': "Respect X-Backend-Etag-Is-At headers from left of SLO

If a middleware left of SLO wants to override the ETag for a large
object, it will need to send a X-Backend-Etag-Is-At on GETs if it wants
to be at all performant. This would work fine coming out of the object
controller (which would look at the headers in the response, figure out
what's the real conditional etag, and pass it to swob.Response), and
even encryption (which would do the same), but at SLO, we'd just replace
the ETag, flag it as a conditional response, and let swob assume the
*SLO* ETag is the conditional one.

Now, SLO will jump through the same resolve_backend_etag_is_at hoops that
other parts of the proxy have to deal with. This allows If-Match and
If-None-Match to work correctly if/when swift3 stores an S3-compatible
multipart-upload ETag.

Change-Id: Ibbf59d38d7bcc9c485b1d5305548144025d77441
"}]
commit_message:
Respect X-Backend-Etag-Is-At headers from left of SLO

If a middleware left of SLO wants to override the ETag for a large
object, it will need to send a X-Backend-Etag-Is-At on GETs if it wants
to be at all performant. This would work fine coming out of the object
controller (which would look at the headers in the response, figure out
what's the real conditional etag, and pass it to swob.Response), and
even encryption (which would do the same), but at SLO, we'd just replace
the ETag, flag it as a conditional response, and let swob assume the
*SLO* ETag is the conditional one.

Now, SLO will jump through the same resolve_backend_etag_is_at hoops that
other parts of the proxy have to deal with. This allows If-Match and
If-None-Match to work correctly if/when swift3 stores an S3-compatible
multipart-upload ETag.

Change-Id: Ibbf59d38d7bcc9c485b1d5305548144025d77441

commit_message:
Using assertIsNone() instead of assertEqual(None)

Following OpenStack Style Guidelines:
[1] http://docs.openstack.org/developer/hacking/#unit-tests-and-assertraises
[H203] Unit test assertions tend to give better messages for more specific
assertions. As a result, assertIsNone(...) is preferred over
assertEqual(None, ...) and assertIs(..., None)

Change-Id: Ide62a2bacd1d03bce90dfb4707dfd6478bc8ed89

I mean with LBaaS support code. :)'}, {'account_id': 21041, 'date': '2018-03-25 08:24:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> I mean with LBaaS support code. :)
@Michal
I assume the best way to 'feel confident' in that case will be
to verify the bug fix, for that purpose  you can run the following:

1. Deploy devstack (K8S + Octavia)
2. Create service of type LoadBalancer as follows:

kubectl run --image=celebdor/kuryr-demo kuryr-demo1
kubectl scale deploy/kuryr-demo1  --replicas=2
kubectl expose deploy/kuryr-demo1 --port 80 --target-port 8080 --type=LoadBalancer


3. Kuryr controller updates the service external (floating) IP under service status as follows:

"
status:
  loadBalancer:
    ingress:
    - ip: <Floating IP>
"
4. We should verify that floating IP is not set under status/loadbalancer/.. while openstack LB is provisioning_status is not active.


Run 'kubectl get svc kuryr-demo1  -o yaml'
and verify IP is not Set
under status till LB 'provisioning_status' is ACTIVE at 
'openstack loadbalancer list''}, {'account_id': 14352, 'date': '2018-03-26 14:52:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 6598, 'date': '2018-03-27 05:50:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

commit_message:
Services: update service's status after LB completely provisioned.

When creating a service of type 'LoadBalancer', you create
a cloud network load balancer.
This provides an externally-accessible IP address that sends
traffic to the correct port on your cluster nodes.
The external IP address is stored in k8s service's status
information (under loadbalancer/ingress/ip).

Kuryr implements this capability using OpenStack floating IP
functionality.
This patch updates Kuryr to store external IP information only after
LB was entirely configured in OpenStack.

Change-Id: I1d43f03d49d6e760c859f219aa9a4c209087c753
Closes-Bug: 1756730

messages:
[{'account_id': 16352, 'date': '2018-04-05 09:25:12.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 22406, 'date': '2018-04-05 10:09:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Hi, I couldn't apply new feature in my environment. I checkout this patch and restart apache2, is these correct steps?"}, {'account_id': 22406, 'date': '2018-04-05 10:11:58.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> Hi, I couldn't apply new feature in my environment. I check out this
 > patch and restart apache2, are these correct steps?"}, {'account_id': 11536, 'date': '2018-04-05 15:42:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> Hi, I couldn't apply new feature in my environment. I checkout this
 > patch and restart apache2, is these correct steps?

Hi @Kien. This is how I tried this patch:

* Go to /opt/stack/zun-ui and apply this patch.
* Go to /opt/stack/horizon and run this command: rm -rf static/ && python manage.py collectstatic --noinput && python manage.py compress --force && sudo service apache2 restart

Hope it will work for you."}, {'account_id': 11536, 'date': '2018-04-05 15:45:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2

From my point of view, this patch worked very well. Very cool. Let's wait for @Kien feedback if he can setup the environment to test this patch."}, {'account_id': 16352, 'date': '2018-04-05 23:45:27.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 16352, 'date': '2018-04-05 23:46:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

My commit message had a lie. sorry.'}, {'account_id': 11536, 'date': '2018-04-06 03:39:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 22406, 'date': '2018-04-06 06:13:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> > Hi, I couldn't apply new feature in my environment. I checkout
 > this
 > > patch and restart apache2, is these correct steps?
 > 
 > Hi @Kien. This is how I tried this patch:
 > 
 > * Go to /opt/stack/zun-ui and apply this patch.
 > * Go to /opt/stack/horizon and run this command: rm -rf static/ &&
 > python manage.py collectstatic --noinput && python manage.py
 > compress --force && sudo service apache2 restart
 > 
 > Hope it will work for you.

I got it, forgot to remove re-collectstatic & compress steps :) Thank you."}, {'account_id': 22406, 'date': '2018-04-06 06:13:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Workflow+1 Code-Review+2

This patch worked well :) Great works.'}, {'account_id': 16352, 'date': '2018-04-06 06:29:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Cherry Picked

commit_message:
Change from py27 to pep8 job in tacker-specs

Remove py27 job because it is not useful,
instead, change to pep8 job to check spec files.

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/558506/
Change-Id: I14d5797279ccfa5130391104e53765b7eba45014

commit_message:
Fix autorun option in reproducer script

In 9251a3ec5ac56015b132d7e77b66068d770c4882 we added a "shift"
after the autorun option. This is incorrect, as autorun does not
take an argument, so there is nothing to shift.

This change removes the unintended shift.

Change-Id: Ibcfbcf39fbeaaa15ecd8e1a2a2085bb2dcbed8c8

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-03-24 03:58:59.000000000', 'message': 'Add playbook to ship journals from hosts

The journal within systemd is able to be shipped from a physical hosts
to a centralized location. This change introduces
`systemd-journal-remote` which will ship all journals on the physical
host to the log host and store the journals under
"/var/log/journal/remote". This change gives deployers greater
visability into the cloud using the systemd built-ins.

> NOTE: This change is all accomplished in a playbook using our common
        roles. While this could be moved into a role by itself, it would
        be a waist of effort given how small this change is.

Given all services are inherently logging to the journal, this change
may allow us to one day deprecate or minimize the usage of our
rsyslog roles. If we were to remove the requirement for rsyslog to run
everywhere we could reduce overall internal cluster IO (CPU, network and
block) and remove the requirement for all services to ship log files from
all containers and hosts. This change is NOT modifying the integrated
logging architecture. At this time we're simply ensuring that the
journals on the physical host are co-located on the logging machines.

Change-Id: I254d52df6303b7cc4d4071b4beaf347922b2616e
Related-Change: https://review.openstack.org/553707
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>
'}, {'created': '2018-03-24 04:39:42.000000000', 'message': 'Add playbook to ship journals from hosts

The journal within systemd is able to be shipped from a physical hosts
to a centralized location. This change introduces
`systemd-journal-remote` which will ship all journals on the physical
host to the log host and store the journals under
"/var/log/journal/remote". This change gives deployers greater
visability into the cloud using the systemd built-ins.

> NOTE: This change is all accomplished in a playbook using our common
        roles. While this could be moved into a role by itself, it would
        be a waist of effort given how small this change is.

Given all services are inherently logging to the journal, this change
may allow us to one day deprecate or minimize the usage of our
rsyslog roles. If we were to remove the requirement for rsyslog to run
everywhere we could reduce overall internal cluster IO (CPU, network and
block) and remove the requirement for all services to ship log files from
all containers and hosts. This change is NOT modifying the integrated
logging architecture. At this time we're simply ensuring that the
journals on the physical host are co-located on the logging machines.

Change-Id: I254d52df6303b7cc4d4071b4beaf347922b2616e
Related-Change: https://review.openstack.org/553707
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>
'}, {'created': '2018-03-24 06:32:17.000000000', 'message': 'Add playbook to ship journals from hosts

The journal within systemd is able to be shipped from a physical hosts
to a centralized location. This change introduces
`systemd-journal-remote` which will ship all journals on the physical
host to the log host and store the journals under
"/var/log/journal/remote". This change gives deployers greater
visability into the cloud using the systemd built-ins.

> NOTE: This change is all accomplished in a playbook using our common
        roles. While this could be moved into a role by itself, it would
        be a waist of effort given how small this change is.

Given all services are inherently logging to the journal, this change
may allow us to one day deprecate or minimize the usage of our
rsyslog roles. If we were to remove the requirement for rsyslog to run
everywhere we could reduce overall internal cluster IO (CPU, network and
block) and remove the requirement for all services to ship log files from
all containers and hosts. This change is NOT modifying the integrated
logging architecture. At this time we're simply ensuring that the
journals on the physical host are co-located on the logging machines.

At this time there's no suitable package available for
systemd-journal-remote on suse so the playbook to install and setup
remote journalling is being omitted when the suse is detected. When a
suitable package is found the playbook omission should be removed.

Change-Id: I254d52df6303b7cc4d4071b4beaf347922b2616e
Related-Change: https://review.openstack.org/553707
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>
'}, {'created': '2018-03-25 03:04:18.000000000', 'message': 'Add playbook to ship journals from hosts

The journal within systemd is able to be shipped from a physical hosts
to a centralized location. This change introduces
`systemd-journal-remote` which will ship all journals on the physical
host to the log host and store the journals under
"/var/log/journal/remote". This change gives deployers greater
visability into the cloud using the systemd built-ins.

> NOTE: This change is all accomplished in a playbook using our common
        roles. While this could be moved into a role by itself, it would
        be a waist of effort given how small this change is.

Given all services are inherently logging to the journal, this change
may allow us to one day deprecate or minimize the usage of our
rsyslog roles. If we were to remove the requirement for rsyslog to run
everywhere we could reduce overall internal cluster IO (CPU, network and
block) and remove the requirement for all services to ship log files from
all containers and hosts. This change is NOT modifying the integrated
logging architecture. At this time we're simply ensuring that the
journals on the physical host are co-located on the logging machines.

At this time there's no suitable package available for
systemd-journal-remote on suse so the playbook to install and setup
remote journalling is being omitted when the suse is detected. When a
suitable package is found the playbook omission should be removed.

Change-Id: I254d52df6303b7cc4d4071b4beaf347922b2616e
Related-Change: https://review.openstack.org/553707
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>

commit_message:
Add playbook to ship journals from hosts

The journal within systemd is able to be shipped from a physical hosts
to a centralized location. This change introduces
`systemd-journal-remote` which will ship all journals on the physical
host to the log host and store the journals under
"/var/log/journal/remote". This change gives deployers greater
visability into the cloud using the systemd built-ins.

> NOTE: This change is all accomplished in a playbook using our common
        roles. While this could be moved into a role by itself, it would
        be a waist of effort given how small this change is.

Given all services are inherently logging to the journal, this change
may allow us to one day deprecate or minimize the usage of our
rsyslog roles. If we were to remove the requirement for rsyslog to run
everywhere we could reduce overall internal cluster IO (CPU, network and
block) and remove the requirement for all services to ship log files from
all containers and hosts. This change is NOT modifying the integrated
logging architecture. At this time we're simply ensuring that the
journals on the physical host are co-located on the logging machines.

At this time there's no suitable package available for
systemd-journal-remote on suse so the playbook to install and setup
remote journalling is being omitted when the suse is detected. When a
suitable package is found the playbook omission should be removed.

Change-Id: I254d52df6303b7cc4d4071b4beaf347922b2616e
Related-Change: https://review.openstack.org/553707
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>

Merge branch 'master' into feature/deep

Most of the conflicts had to do with Sam's recent replicator
improvements.

commit_message:
Drop unnecessary clean-ups for Puppet

Nodepool images no longer have Puppet in them anymore so there
is no point in removing files and packages which are not there
anymore in the first place.

Change-Id: Idb89512251ca9125fcb3f44768873d2cb76eb879

commit_message:
Move misplaced objects when cleaving

Before, when cleaving a shard, only objects that fell within a
destination shard range were cleaved. Any misplaced objects *may* have
been dealt with by a previous invocation of the misplaced objects
handler, but that was not guaranteed.

This patch introduces a further call to misplaced objects specifically
to move any misplaced objects in the database that is being cleaved.

Change-Id: Idd12682529b2da9dc54aa2c4c925d9bb30374a4a

reviewers: [{'_account_id': 1131, 'name': 'Brian Haley', 'email': 'haleyb.dev@gmail.com', 'username': 'brian-haley'}, {'_account_id': 4694, 'name': 'Miguel Lavalle', 'email': 'miguel@mlavalle.com', 'username': 'minsel'}, {'_account_id': 7016, 'name': 'Swaminathan Vasudevan', 'email': 'swvasude@cisco.com', 'username': 'souminathan'}, {'_account_id': 9732, 'name': 'Mellanox CI', 'email': 'mlnx-openstack-ci@dev.mellanox.co.il', 'username': 'mellanox', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 10385, 'name': 'Citrix XenServer CI', 'username': 'citrix_xenserver_ci', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 15752, 'name': 'Intel SR-IOV CI', 'email': 'sriov-ci@intel.com', 'username': 'sriovci', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 16376, 'name': 'Intel NFV CI', 'email': 'openstack-nfv-ci@intel.com', 'username': 'intel-nfv-ci', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 17120, 'name': 'Manjeet Singh Bhatia', 'email': 'manjeet.s.bhatia@intel.com', 'username': 'manjeets'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 24824, 'name': 'Dmitrii Shcherbakov', 'email': 'dmitrii.shcherbakov@canonical.com', 'username': 'dmitriis'}]

[{'account_id': 24824, 'date': '2018-03-29 21:48:04.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 7016, 'date': '2018-03-29 23:57:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Looks good to me.
Let me see how the zuul runs.'}, {'account_id': 24824, 'date': '2018-03-30 00:17:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Thanks for the review, appreciate the prior work on the subject.'}, {'account_id': 7016, 'date': '2018-03-30 17:39:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

recheck volume failures'}, {'account_id': 24824, 'date': '2018-03-31 06:39:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I think this change surfaced another issue: there is a mismatch between adding and deleting a fip rule from a qrouter namespace as different addresses are currently used:

test_dvr_router_floating_ip_moved

http://logs.openstack.org/36/557836/1/check/neutron-functional/cced618/logs/dsvm-functional-logs/neutron.tests.functional.agent.l3.extensions.test_fip_qos_extension.TestL3AgentFipQosExtensionDVR.test_dvr_router_floating_ip_moved.txt.gz#_2018-03-30_17_52_01_097

['ip', 'netns', 'exec', 'qrouter-b94ca5e8-faa2-46dd-a4f1-b46073f1586f', 'ip', '-4', 'rule', 'add', 'from', '10.0.0.1', 'priority', '39010', 'table', '16', 'type', 'unicast']

Floating IP was moved from fixed IP 10.0.0.1 to 10.0.0.2 process_floating_ip_addresses neutron/agent/l3/router_info.py:368

['ip', 'netns', 'exec', 'qrouter-b94ca5e8-faa2-46dd-a4f1-b46073f1586f', 'ip', '-4', 'rule', 'del', 'from', '19.4.4.2', 'priority', '39010', 'table', '16', 'type', 'unicast'] execute_rootwrap_daemon neutron/agent/linux/utils.py:108 

Code-wise:

https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/7322bd6efb6e61acb2e967be22f84554d064ec7e/neutron/agent/l3/dvr_local_router.py#L127
    def _add_floating_ip_rule(self, floating_ip, fixed_ip):
...
        ip_rule.rule.add(ip=fixed_ip,

https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/7322bd6efb6e61acb2e967be22f84554d064ec7e/neutron/agent/l3/dvr_local_router.py#L131
    def _remove_floating_ip_rule(self, floating_ip):
...
            ip_rule.rule.delete(ip=floating_ip,

So, a rule is added correctly but is not removed correctly. The problem has not lead to failures before as only address family was used, not the ip itself and iproute2 deleted a rule without matching by an IP address.


The second problem: as implemented so far the namespace layout depends on the fact that only one router can be attached to a given provider network as fip-<ext-network-uuid> naming is used for fip namespaces while qrouter-<router-uuid> is used for qrouter namespaces. So, for now, there is only one policy rule created in a fip namespace:

sudo ip netns exec fip-d0f008fc-dc45-4237-9ce0-a9e1977735eb ip rule

0:	from all lookup local
32766:	from all lookup main
32767:	from all lookup default
2852022899:	from all iif fpr-4f9ca9ef-3 lookup 2852022899

When it gets deleted here https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/7b82892/neutron/agent/l3/dvr_fip_ns.py#L396-L402, an address does not need to be used as there is an assumption that 'from all iif <veth-end-to-qrouter> lookup <tablename>' will be used and a link-local address such as 169.254.106.115 will only be used to determine an IP protocol version. With the current patchset it leads to the following command and iproute2 cannot match that against any existing rule and fails:

2018-03-30 17:52:29.421 10048 DEBUG neutron.agent.linux.utils [req-31adb44c-6078-49d3-850a-426f74a22525 - - - - -] Running command (rootwrap daemon): ['ip', 'netns', 'exec', 'fip-ce2ec556-c3b7-4a34-ad84-d7f80a9160ee', 'ip', '-4', 'rule', 'del', 'from', '169.254.106.115', 'iif', 'fpr-1629f610-a', 'priority', '2852022899', 'table', '2852022899', 'type', 'unicast'] execute_rootwrap_daemon neutron/agent/linux/utils.py:108

A simple test shows that we do not need to pass 'all' to the rule deletion function and can pass 0.0.0.0/0 or ::/0 instead:

root@test:~# ip rule add from all iif br0 lookup 0

root@test:~# ip rule
0:	from all lookup local 
32765:	from all iif br0 lookup 1 
32766:	from all lookup main 
32767:	from all lookup default 

root@test:~# ip rule delete from 0.0.0.0/0 iif br0 lookup 0

root@test:~# ip rule
0:	from all lookup local 
32766:	from all lookup main 
32767:	from all lookup default 


In [1]: import netaddr
In [2]: netaddr.IPNetwork('0.0.0.0/0').version
Out[2]: 4
In [3]: netaddr.IPNetwork('::/0').version
Out[3]: 6

So /0 addresses of an appropriate family can be passed so that the rule removal is properly handled in terms of a protocol version."}, {'account_id': 24824, 'date': '2018-03-31 23:19:05.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 24824, 'date': '2018-04-01 02:26:13.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 24824, 'date': '2018-04-01 02:28:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Patch set 3 should take care of the last neutron-functional test failure. Special handling for iff-based rules needs to be mirrored in the delete function.

http://logs.openstack.org/36/557836/2/check/neutron-functional/ebacdfb/logs/testr_results.html.gz'}, {'account_id': 24824, 'date': '2018-04-01 03:36:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

This failure in neutron-fullstack seems unrelated to the change:

http://logs.openstack.org/36/557836/3/check/neutron-fullstack/6d9c146/logs/testr_results.html.gz

http://logs.openstack.org/36/557836/3/check/neutron-fullstack/6d9c146/logs/dsvm-fullstack-logs/TestDhcpAgentHA.test_reschedule_network_on_new_agent_Linux-bridge-agent_.txt.gz#_2018-04-01_02_54_06_833'}, {'account_id': 7016, 'date': '2018-04-02 18:27:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 7016, 'date': '2018-04-03 18:31:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(1 comment)

nit: in comments'}, {'account_id': 24824, 'date': '2018-04-03 19:23:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

I only changed comments though in the last patchset.
